Many supporters packed the IASH conference room of the Glenn G. Bartle Library to listen to Professor Herbert Bix give his lecture titled “Empire Building in America and Japan: The Breakdown of Constitutional Order,” Nov. 1st. The lecture was followed by a reception in honor of Bix’s retirement.  A world-renowned scholar of the political, military and social history of 19th- and 20th-century Japan, Bix is the author of Hirohito and the Making of Modern Japan (HarperCollins, 2000), which won the Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award. He also authored Peasant Protest in Japan, 1590-1884 (Yale, 1986) as well as numerous other print and digital publications.  The tribute to Bix’s illustrious career and his contributions to Binghamton University was hosted by the departments of sociology and history at Harpur College.

Hornsby’s commercial stock soared early on when “The Way It Is” became the most-played song on American radio in 1987, winning ASCAP’s Song of the Year award. He performed over 100 concerts with the Grateful Dead and his eclectic musical interests have led him into jazz, classical, bluegrass and even electronica.

Binghamton University’s sculpture program hosts the seventh annual Invitational Iron Pour. Over 100 molds were poured using Binghamton’s two furnaces as well as two others brought in by the invited programs. Independent professional sculptors known for their work in iron also participated. Eighty-two student teams demonstrated interactive objects using Arduino, an open-source prototyping platform. Tenzin Norbu, a monk from Namgyal Monastery, demonstrates the creation of a Sand Mandala at the University Art Museum in the Fine Arts Building, during Family Weekend. Acting as cultural ambassadors from the exiled personal monastery of His Holiness the Dalai Lama in Dharamsala, India, the monks of Namgyal Monastery Institute of Buddhist Studies have become especially well known for the creation of Sand Mandala exhibitions in museums and galleries throughout the world. Millions of grains of sand are painstakingly laid into place on a flat platform over a period of days before ultimately being dismantled in order to release and disseminate the deity’s blessings into the world to benefit all sentient beings.

Binghamton University’s sculpture program hosts the sixth annual Invitational Iron Pour in the sculpture studios in the Fine Arts Building on campus. Over 100 molds were poured using Binghamton’s two furnaces as well as three others brought in by the invited programs. The process involves pouring white-hot iron, raised to temperatures of more than 2,700 degrees, into special molds to create sculptures.
